rev.diff:
Line 1: Line 1: â
The '''New York shirtwaist strike of 1909''', also known as the '''Uprising of the 20,000''', was a labor [[strike action|strike]] primarily involving [[Jew]]ish women working in New York shirtwaist factories. Led by [[Clara Lemlich]] and supported by the [[Women's Trade Union League|National Women's Trade Union League of America]] (NWTUL), the strike began in November, 1909. In February, 1910, the NWTUL settled with the factory owners, gaining improved wages, working conditions, and hours.<ref name=sachar>Sachar.</ref>
+
The '''New York shirtwaist strike of 1909''', also known as the '''Uprising of the 20,000''',[http://www.ashp.cuny.edu/heaven/uprising.html] was a labor [[strike action|strike]] primarily involving [[Jew]]ish women working in New York shirtwaist factories. Led by [[Clara Lemlich]] and supported by the [[Women's Trade Union League|National Women's Trade Union League of America]] (NWTUL), the strike began in November, 1909. In February, 1910, the NWTUL settled with the factory owners, gaining improved wages, working conditions, and hours.<ref name=sachar>Sachar.</ref>

known as the Uprising of the 30,000 (not 20,000)
